definition: oblique tone/nonlevel tone/uneven tone (the third tone of Classical Chinese)
level or even tone/first and second tones in modern Mandarin
falling tone/fourth tone in modern Mandarin
entering tone/checked tone/one of the four tones of Middle Chinese
level and oblique tones (technical term for Classical Chinese rhythmic poetry)
rhyming word ending a line of verse/rhyme
antithesis (two lines of poetry matching in sense and sound)/to fight/to wage war
the final of a Chinese syllable (the component of a syllable remaining after removal of the initial consonant, if any, and the tone, e.g. the final of "niáng" is "iang")
(phonology) coda, the part of a syllable that follows its vocalic nucleus (e.g. "u" in kòu or "n" in běn)
falling and rising tone/third tone in modern Mandarin
regular verse/strict poetic form with eight lines of 5, 6 or 7 syllables and even lines rhyming
rhyme entry/subdivision of a rhyming dictionary (containing all words with the given rhyme)
